column1: natigail 160912270589 "2017-05-21 16:01:51 GMT" http://natigail.tumblr.com/post/160912270589/tickettome-kurasawas-tickettome-just-got "tickettome: kurasawas:  tickettome:  Just got done reading an interesting article about how language affects the way we think and perceive the world. There were some interesting examples. Like how in Spanish
column4: it is feminine. So native speakers of these languages describe the same thing differently. Spanish speakers will comment on how strong or sturdy a bridge is
column5: while German speakers will comment on how elegant or beautiful it is. Another example that blew my mind was the Guugu Yimithirr language. So
column8: use an egocentric type of directional language (turn right
column11: in front.) these directions are relative to you as a person. Well
column12: the Guugu Yimithirr language uses fixed geographical directions (North
column15: and West) no matter the context. If you were to put an English speaker and a Guugu Yimithirr speaker in the same hotel
column16: and put them in rooms opposite sides of the hallway from each other
column17: the English speaker will see the exact same room (that person will see the desk to the right of blah and the closet in front of blah) but the Guugu Yimithirr speaker will see a COMPLETELY different room because the bed will be facing south instead of north
column18: and all of that jazz. And the article went on to state how speakers of this language might even have a lower sense of egotism
column19: because directions do not revolve around them
column20: theyâ€™re just another part of the picture. Really fascinating.It made me think really long about language imperialism and how rapidly weâ€™re moving towards a world that deals almost exclusively in English. It makes me sad to know that weâ€™re losing completely different ways of thinking. Completely different perspectives
column21: just gone. I guess thatâ€™s why I always get upset when people say that language imperialism isnâ€™t so bad
column22: and that English as a language is connecting people together. The world is a great big place
column24: and I think the fastest way to kill a culture is to take away the language
column25: because not only are you taking away a method of communication
column26: but a way of thinking.  Edit: since I forgot to put the source in and itâ€™s getting traction https://mobile.nytimes.com/2010/08/29/magazine/29language-t.html?_r=0&referer=  linguistic imperialism is real and takes place in large part because of the importance (re: monetary

column30: and well within the dialects of them too however
column31: language DOES NOT affect the way a person thinks. this is not at all true. that theory is known as the sapir-whorf hypothesis
column34: and just about anyone worth their grain of salt in the realm of language would disagree against it in a large extent because language Does Not affect the way you think. these examples are just examples of the way socialization and cultural principles you adapt take part in the way you speak
column35: but it doesnâ€™t necessarily tie directly into how you perceive the world language is merely a tool thatâ€™s really only developed in our species in a much shorter time than weâ€™re generally aware of. humans use it to express the millions upon millions of abstractions and thoughts that we harbor internally and often have to limit what it is we want to express based on whatever language or languages you speak. while it is true that you experience conceptualizations based on your language
column37: and the linguistic culture youâ€™re a part of for that code
column38: those conceptualizations themselves that you develop are based on your own thought. influence
column41: but they are not mutually exclusive components. you need language to talk about what you think
column44: if you constantly find yourself having difficulty expressing yourself - human language is just so limited in achieving a complete
column45: successful expression of thought the â€œbridge has different semantic meaning in languages bc of gender etc.â€ is a very common argument used in linguistic determinism but it holds no weight in reality. as a multilingual person
column46: i donâ€™t suddenly think of something like â€œtableâ€ as womanly
column48: or anything like that simply because in one of my languages it takes on the feminine gender. i donâ€™t suddenly become unable to count a handful of pens in English just because i use a different set of counters in Japanese for objects like pens specifically. likewise
column49: i have no issue perceiving them as simply being pens when i identify them using counter words in Japanese; they are still what they are

natigail 160874689785 "2017-05-20 15:01:08 GMT" http://natigail.tumblr.com/post/160874689785/yes-i-do-teach-creative-writing-your-opening "underhillwriter:  The opening scene is the most important piece of your novel. This scene determines whether your reader is pulled in or puts the book down. Here are some important doâ€™s and donâ€™ts. DO write it as a scene
column2: not a data dump. You may have a fantastic premise
column3: a marvelous alternate history or post-apocalyptic world or magical realism to die for
column4: but if you donâ€™t engage your reader in an actual scene
column5: you will bore them. DO write a scene that immediately introduces a character that the reader can root for. Yes
column6: I know Stephen King has had great success introducing victims that are then shortly afterward killed off. Thatâ€™s a horror trope and we expect it. But if you are caught up in world-building and havenâ€™t dreamed your way into a character who is worth following through 100
column8: your story is pointless. I have read many pieces of fiction by would-be writers who canâ€™t grasp this essential concept
column10: they fail to engage the reader. DO introduce the stakes right away. In case thatâ€™s a challenge that needs some exposition to develop
column11: create some immediate stakes (a life threat works) that keep the tension high and the reader engaged until you can lay out the larger stakes. DO begin in medias res
column12: which meansÂ â€œin the middle of things.â€ Most beginning fiction writers make the mistake of starting too early in the plot. Meet the monster on page 1.Â  DONâ€™T include a flashback in the first chapter. Work on a scene
column13: which means time is NOT compressed. It should include dialog
column17: and interior monolog. Keep everything happening within that scene for at least the first chapter. You can bring in a flashback in Chapter Three. DONâ€™T shift points of view within a single chapter. Let the reader establish a strong bond of interest (even if itâ€™s with a POV villain) over the course of a whole chapter. DONâ€™T open the story with your character waking up unless itâ€™s because sheâ€™s got a gun in her face (or a knife to her throat â€“ you get what I mean). We donâ€™t need to follow a character through their mundane daily routine.Â  DONâ€™T be coy. Beginning writers often have this idea that they need to hold back on revealing all their secrets â€“ whatâ€™s in the box
column20: etc. Their well-meant plan is to slowly reveal all this over several chapters. Trust me on this one: tell your readers instead of keeping it a mystery. You WILL come up with more secrets to reveal. Your imagination is that good. Spill it now
column21: and allow that revelation to add to the excitement. " False text

natigail 160702302684 "2017-05-15 18:30:41 GMT" http://natigail.tumblr.com/post/160702302684/secretlywritingstories-my-limbs-feel-heavy-today "secretlywritingstories:My limbs feel heavy today. I feel like I want to do things but at the same time I just want to curl under my blanket and hide in my bed surrounded by unhealthy snacks while watching my favourite shows or YouTube videos. Itâ€™s been a long weekend full of social interaction and I always seem to forget how much that tears into me and makes me feel fragile. Sometimes when I finally get alone after long days
column2: I will feel like the slightest nudge will make me fracture and shatter to pieces. This past weekend I participated in a dressage competition with my horse - something I used to do more regularly when I was younger but over the last few years life has just gotten in the way. I was never highly competitive but when the weekend started out I could feel that special thing in the air: anticipation for the days that were about to pass. So many of my friends and their horses would compete as well and I was excited for my stables to host the competition. Two days later and after two dressage programmes
column3: I just feel a bit empty and like Iâ€™m at a stand-still. I made the mistake of reading through old assessments and upon reading the judgeâ€™s commentary I feel like Iâ€™ve gotten stuck and not improved as much as I should. Itâ€™s a ridiculous notion because I never got a horse for the competitive aspect of it. I love our day to day training or going for a forest ride or just spending bonding time with her
column4: so I donâ€™t know why this is hitting me so hard. I have an answer
column6: but I donâ€™t like it. Iâ€™m just feeling overwhelmed and tomorrow this hollow feeling will leave me and Iâ€™ll have forgotten all about these thoughts. I become vulnerable and sensitive when I donâ€™t have the time to stop and breathe and step away from everything. Luckily
column7: I had nothing on the schedule until this evening
column8: so Iâ€™ve been confining myself to my bed and watching loads of YouTube videos. However
column9: thereâ€™s that nagging in the back of my mind that Iâ€™m wasting my precious timeÂ â€œrechargingâ€ - I should do my university readings
column10: I should write the stories that sit unfinished on my computer
column11: I should have gone for a run or at least a walk with my dog
column12: I should have written down my feelings about this past weekend while the memories are still fresh
column13: I should have gotten into the shower hours ago. Life is strange and I donâ€™t know what to do about that. I have my logical side that still is hitting myself over the head for wasting my limited time
column14: even as my mind begs me to take this time and not feel guilty about it. All of this will fade soon and if I manage to drag myself into the shower (I will because Iâ€™m a stubborn bastard and I already feel lighter after writing these words)
column15: the warm water will wash over my body and my tense joints will loosen up and my mind will clear momentarily. Iâ€™ll grab this clarity and run with it because in two hours Iâ€™m heading out the door with my family to see a show. Life goes on even when you just want to dig in your heels and tell everything to slow down. Iâ€™m the type of person that doesnâ€™t want to miss out on anything
column16: so I wonâ€™t stay home. Iâ€™ll stop writing now and go turn on the shower. If anyone is reading this
column17: Iâ€™m sorry if my melancholy rubbed off on you. Honestly
column18: I will be all better in just an hour - I can feel the fog in my mind lifting already. Maybe
column19: if you were to get anything from this
column20: let this be a reminder (both to you and my future self) that it doesnâ€™t do you any good to look back at the past and feel sad you didnâ€™t do as well as you might have expected. You probably did do a lot but you canâ€™t see it if you turn on a narrow self-deprevating vision. I love my horse dearly and I know for a fact weâ€™ve gotten better at working together over the last few years even if I donâ€™t have judgesâ€™ assessments to prove it. I donâ€™t need them. I know us better than they ever will for the five minute we perform in front of their watchful eyes. I know Iâ€™ve moved forward and I know I need time to recharge after spending too much time with people. Itâ€™s okay. Iâ€™m okay. If youâ€™ve ever felt like I do at this very moment
column21: trust yourself to know that itâ€™ll be okay.Â  Whoops
column22: my hand slipped and I spilled some words onto my screen. It felt very therapeutic to write this." False text
